description: This updates the docs to talk about the new colormaps.
title: Update documentation about colormaps.  Closes #1199.

content.raw: Any idea why the new one doesn't include the new matplotlib colormaps? (i.e. viridis, magma).
content.html: Any idea why the new one doesn't include the new matplotlib colormaps? (i.e. viridis, magma).

content.raw: Not sure.  I'm on 1.5.1.  What should I be on?
content.html: Not sure. I'm on 1.5.1. What should I be on?

content.raw: Also, maybe I should also rotate this.  I'll fix that when I fix the other, although I used the script Cameron suggested, so I'm not sure what happened there.
content.html: Also, maybe I should also rotate this. I'll fix that when I fix the other, although I used the script Cameron suggested, so I'm not sure what happened there.

content.raw: Not sure.  I'm on 1.5.1.  What should I be on?
content.html: Not sure. I'm on 1.5.1. What should I be on?

content.raw: All the new colormaps should be in 1.5.1. I'd need to look closer at the script that generates these images to figure out why they're not showing up.
content.html: All the new colormaps should be in 1.5.1. I'd need to look closer at the script that generates these images to figure out why they're not showing up.

content.raw:
There are still a few places where we're using algae:

```
goldbaum at ROUS2 in ~/Documents/yt-hg/yt on yt!? 📑  volume-source-refactor
☿ grin algae
./testing.py:
  430 :     >>> keywords['cmap'] = ('algae', 'jet')
  434 :     array([{'cmap': 'algae', 'dpi': 50},
  436 :            {'cmap': 'algae', 'dpi': 200}], dtype=object)
  441 :     array([{'cmap': 'algae', 'dpi': 50},
  442 :            {'cmap': 'algae', 'dpi': 100},
  443 :            {'cmap': 'algae', 'dpi': 200},
./visualization/_colormap_data.py:
  190 : ### algae ###
  192 : color_map_luts['algae'] = \
./visualization/color_maps.py:
   72 : add_cmap('algae', cdict)
  201 :         Example: ['algae', 'gist_stern', 'kamae', 'spectral']
./visualization/eps_writer.py:
 1047 :     >>> cbs.append(return_cmap("algae", "Density [cm$^{-3}$]", (0,10), False))
 1367 :     >>> cb = return_cmap("algae", "Density [cm$^{-3}$]", (0,10), False)
./visualization/image_writer.py:
  289 :             cmaps = ("jet", "algae", "hot", "gist_stern", "RdBu",
./visualization/tests/test_offaxisprojection.py:
   68 :     wp_kwargs['cmap_name'] = ('algae', 'jet')
./visualization/volume_rendering/input_events.py:
  242 :     cmap = ['algae', 'kamae', 'viridis', 'inferno', 'magma']
./visualization/volume_rendering/interactive_vr.py:
  118 :         cmap = cm.get_cmap("algae")   # TODO: get default_cmap
./visualization/volume_rendering/render_source.py:
  547 :         this MeshSource object. Should be a string, like 'algae', or 'hot'.
./visualization/volume_rendering/transfer_functions.py:
  666 :         >>> tf.sample_colormap(-7.0, 0.01, colormap='algae')
  712 :         >>> tf.map_to_colormap(-8.0, -6.0, scale=10.0, colormap='algae')
  713 :         >>> tf.map_to_colormap(-6.0, -5.0, scale=10.0, colormap='algae',
```

In particular in the interactive VR, as well as in a few docstrings still.

content.raw: I'll fix those up as well

content.raw:
I'm just doing this:

```
import yt
yt.show_colormaps("yt_native", "source/visualizing/_images/native_yt_colormaps.png")
yt.show_colormaps("all", "./source/visualizing/_images/all_colormaps.png")
```

I see the problem; viridis is not in `.datad` in `matplotlib.cm`.  I'll fix it and make the change an update to this PR.
content.html:
I'm just doing this:

import yt
yt.show_colormaps("yt_native", "source/visualizing/_images/native_yt_colormaps.png")
yt.show_colormaps("all", "./source/visualizing/_images/all_colormaps.png")

I see the problem; viridis is not in .datad in matplotlib.cm. I'll fix it and make the change an update to this PR.

content.raw: Is there any reason for us to continue to have two separate colormap designations?  native yt versus all?  I thought it was a holdover from v2, but maybe I'm wrong and there is reason to keep the distinction.  If not, we could avoid adding a new png file to the repository and just not reference this ``native_yt_colormaps.png`` file from the docs.
content.html: Is there any reason for us to continue to have two separate colormap designations? native yt versus all? I thought it was a holdover from v2, but maybe I'm wrong and there is reason to keep the distinction. If not, we could avoid adding a new png file to the repository and just not reference this native_yt_colormaps.png file from the docs.
